Line 27: Line 27:
He is a graduate of the [[American University in Cairo]] where he was detained and [[torture]]d by Egyptian ruler [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s [[State Security Investigations Service]] (SSI) in 2000, allegedly with the institution's complicity.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/9286/Egypt/Politics-/Students-of-Egypts-American-University-question-it.aspx | title=Students of Egypt's American University question its ties to Mubarak's regime | publisher=Ahram Online | date=7 April 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> He is regarded as "influential" according to a 2007 US intelligence report obtained by [[Wikileaks]].<ref>http://cablesearch.org/cable/view.php?id=07CAIRO1283</ref>
He is a graduate of the [[American University in Cairo]] where he was detained and [[torture]]d by Egyptian ruler [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s [[State Security Investigations Service]] (SSI) in 2000, allegedly with the institution's complicity.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/9286/Egypt/Politics-/Students-of-Egypts-American-University-question-it.aspx | title=Students of Egypt's American University question its ties to Mubarak's regime | publisher=Ahram Online | date=7 April 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> He is regarded as "influential" according to a 2007 US intelligence report obtained by [[Wikileaks]].<ref>http://cablesearch.org/cable/view.php?id=07CAIRO1283</ref>
â
After the [[2011 Egyptian revolution|Egyptian revolution]] of 2011, el-Hamalawy was among many protesters who stormed and seized offices of the SSI in the [[Nasr City]] and was able to visit the cell where he had been imprisoned, later writing on his [[Twitter]] feed that he could not stop crying.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/10/world/middleeast/10cairo.html?hp | title=Egyptians Get View of Extent of Spying | publisher=The New York Times | date=9 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> "Entered the small compound where I was locked. Man, I can't believe it still... Many are literally crying. We can't find the interrogation rooms. This is a citadel."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/03/2011368410372200.html | title=A first step towards prosecutions? | publisher=Al Jazeera | date=6 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref>
+
After the [[2011 Egyptian revolution|Egyptian revolution]] of 2011, el-Hamalawy was among many protesters who stormed and seized offices of the SSI in [[Nasr City]] and was able to visit the cell where he had been imprisoned, later writing on his [[Twitter]] feed that he could not stop crying.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/10/world/middleeast/10cairo.html?hp | title=Egyptians Get View of Extent of Spying | publisher=The New York Times | date=9 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> "Entered the small compound where I was locked. Man, I can't believe it still... Many are literally crying. We can't find the interrogation rooms. This is a citadel."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/03/2011368410372200.html | title=A first step towards prosecutions? | publisher=Al Jazeera | date=6 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref>
Since storming the SSI offices, el-Hamalawy has become the main force behind a "naming and shaming" website "(''Piggipedia'')" targeting former SSI personnel who were involved in the alleged torture of dissidents. Their names are linked to allegations and photos.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle-east/egypts-activists-turn-tables-on-tormentors/2011/04/30/AFEdLV1G_print.html | title=Egyptâs activists turn tables on tormentors | publisher=The Washington Post | date=13 May 2011 | accessdate=13 May 2011}}</ref>
Since storming the SSI offices, el-Hamalawy has become the main force behind a "naming and shaming" website "(''Piggipedia'')" targeting former SSI personnel who were involved in the alleged torture of dissidents. Their names are linked to allegations and photos.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle-east/egypts-activists-turn-tables-on-tormentors/2011/04/30/AFEdLV1G_print.html | title=Egyptâs activists turn tables on tormentors | publisher=The Washington Post | date=13 May 2011 | accessdate=13 May 2011}}</ref>
